   Assessment and Plan
   61 year old gentleman with refractory multiple myeloma admitted on
   [**2165-2-25**] now with atrial fibrillation with RVR and septic shock.
   .
   # Hemorrhagic shock:  Actively bleeding now (>5 L of blood loss via NG
   and rectum) and being resuscitated with blood products through massive
   transfusion protocol.  His wife is at the bedside and discussing
   possible palliative care.  IR willing to try to embolize one more time
   (final attempt to get last segment of GDA) but patient
s weight exceeds
   limit of table on this campus, and he is too unstable to be transported
   to [**Hospital Ward Name **].  Surgery being consulted as last resort.  Two previous
   GI bleeds in past few days both sent to IR for embolization.  Patient
   had episode of hypotension due to upper GI bleed, not responsive to
   fluids, requiring levophed.  Received 7 units RBCs, 1 unit platelets, 5
   L IVF prior to IR embolization on [**6-27**], and 2 units PRBCs with 8
   additional units crossmatched on [**6-28**].
   -Decreased methylprednisone to 20mg [**Hospital1 7**] in effort to decrease steroids
   to assist with ulcer healing
   - surgery reconsulted for possible emergent procedure
   - neo drip to maintain SBP and massive transfusion protocol
   .
   # Bacteremia: Pt with continued enterococcus bacteremia resistant to
   vancomycin.
   - surveillance blood cx today
   - Linezolid and gent for VRE
   - Continue [**Name (NI) 9261**] (pt now desensitized)
 increase to q6h dosing for
   ESBL E.coli in urine
   - Cipro and [**Last Name (un) 614**] for pseudomonas in sputum and blood
   - Gentamicin 250mg IV daily checking peak and trough on 4th dose as per
   ID.  (day 3 today)
   - Decreased dose of gent to 220mg daily; Gent Peak/trough on [**6-29**]
   (ordered), [**7-1**]
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Pt had been doing well on AC in the setting of
   acute GI bleed.
   - Continue AC vent, wean down as tolerated
   - Continue antibiotics as above
   .
   # Edema: Pt received a lot of blood products and IVF for the acute
   bleed.  Will reassess fluid status.
   - holding diuresis for today given large amount of products he received
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR:  Pt remains tachycardic s/p amniodarone
   drip and many other rate/rhythm control methods.
   -Monitor HR
   .
   # Anemia: Pt s/p two IR sessions of embolization over past two days
   after massive GI bleed today with likely source being duodenal ulcer.
   Patient received 7 units pRBCs [**6-27**] and 2 units [**6-28**].
   - check hct q6 hours
   - transfuse to keep Hct>25
   - guaiac stools
   - check and trend Ca
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia
 stable, received 3 unit platelets yesterday to
   maintain plts > 50
   - Plt goal > 50 for acute bleed
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   - restart TPN today, nutrition increased insulin to 65 units
   - continue ISS
   .
   # Renal failure:  Creatinine stable after hemorrhagic shock but will
   continue to monitor for signs of ATN
   - monitor UOP, creatinine
   - maintain UOP>30 with LR and blood as needed
   .
   # Small gap metabolic acidosis present with concomitant nongap
   acidosis; likely due to massive volume resuscitation.
   -LR instead of NS for IVF
   .
   # LFT abnormalities: With e/o cholestatic picture with transaminitis of
   unclear etiology.  DDx include hemolysis, acalculous cholecystits, med
   effect, progression of GVHD to liver.
   - Trend LFTs at this time.
   .
   #. Multiple myeloma - admitted on [**2165-2-25**] now s/p mini-allogeneic SCT:
   His course has been extremely complicated and now with increasing
   immunosuppression for GVHD.  Per BMT, currently in remission.
   - appreciate BMT recs
   - cont immunosuppressants
   - Hem/Onc: Start Foscarnet 90mg/kg [**Hospital1 7**] for empiric CMV treatment (based
   on ideal body weight)- 72 inches --> 80kg ==> 7200mg [**Hospital1 7**].--> will need
   [**Hospital1 7**] lytes. Med not started overnight given need for large fluid
   requirements prior to and during med infusion- awaiting ID opinion
   - cont ppx with atovaquone, acyclovir & voriconazole
   .
   # Access
 now has R PICC, A line, R IJ
   .
   # Sacral decubitus ulcer:
   - Wound care
   .
   # Goals of care:
    -DNR and wife is currently discussing his prognosis/condition with the
   BMT team, our team and surgery to decide how to proceed.  He has
   received 2 coolers full of blood products and is now on cooler 3 of
   massive transfusion protocol still with active hemorrhage.  His wife
   mentioned interest in palliative care and they were consulted but not
   available over the weekend.  Social work contact[**Name (NI) **] instead.
   ICU Care

   TPN w/ Lipids - [**2165-6-29**] 06:15 PM 84 mL/hour

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old gentleman with refractory multiple myeloma, admitted on [**2165-2-25**] and now with atrial fibrillation with RVR and septic shock. The patient has experienced a massive GI bleed, requiring a massive transfusion protocol, and has received multiple units of blood products. He has also undergone two IR sessions of embolization over the past two days.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamic instability, with a SBP of 80s and ongoing bleeding from the rectum
* Respiratory failure, with a FiO2 of 40% and ongoing oxygen therapy
* Renal failure, with a creatinine level of 1.1
* Thrombocytopenia, with a platelet count of 51
* Anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 10.6 g/dL
* Hyperglycemia, with a blood glucose level of 178 mg/dL
* Small gap metabolic acidosis, with a pH of 7.35

The patient's medical conditions and potential complications are:

* Hemorrhagic shock, with ongoing bleeding and hypotension
* Bacteremia, with Enterococcus faecium resistance to vancomycin
* Respiratory failure, with ongoing oxygen therapy and potential need for intubation
* Renal failure, with ongoing fluid management and potential need for dialysis
* Thrombocytopenia, with ongoing bleeding risk and potential need for platelet transfusions
* Anemia, with ongoing bleeding risk and potential need for blood transfusions
* Hyperglycemia, with ongoing insulin therapy and potential need for further management
* Small gap metabolic acidosis, with ongoing fluid management and potential need for further management
* LFT abnormalities, with ongoing monitoring and potential need for further management
* Multiple myeloma, with ongoing immunosuppression and potential need for further management

The patient's goals of care are:

* DNR (do not resuscitate)
* Palliative care consultation, with ongoing discussion with the patient's wife and BMT team

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Ongoing fluid management with LR instead of NS for IVF
* Ongoing antibiotics for bacteremia
* Ongoing antiviral therapy for CMV
* Ongoing immunosuppressants for GVHD
* Ongoing wound care for sacral decubitus ulcer
* Ongoing nutrition with TPN and lipids
* Ongoing glycemic control with ISS

The patient's potential complications and risks include:

* Continued bleeding and hypotension
* Respiratory failure and potential need for intubation
* Renal failure and potential need for dialysis
* Thrombocytopenia and potential need for platelet transfusions
* Anemia and potential need for blood transfusions
* Hyperglycemia and potential need for further management
* Small gap metabolic acidosis and potential need for further management
* LFT abnormalities and potential need for further management
* Multiple myeloma and potential need for further management

The patient's current condition and potential complications require close monitoring and ongoing management to ensure optimal care and patient outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old gentleman with refractory multiple myeloma who has been admitted to the ICU due to atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and septic shock. The patient has a complex medical history, including a recent mini-allogeneic stem cell transplant for multiple myeloma, and has developed various complications, including:

1. Hemorrhagic shock: The patient had a massive gastrointestinal bleed overnight and through the morning, requiring a massive transfusion protocol.
2. Sepsis: The patient has Enterococcus bacteremia resistant to vancomycin, and is being treated with linezolid and gentamicin for VRE.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient is on assisted ventilation (AC) and is being weaned as tolerated.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine has increased to 1.4, likely due to hypotensive episodes during hemorrhagic shock.
5. Anasarca: The patient has received a large amount of blood products and IV fluids, and will be reassessed for fluid status.
6. Atrial fibrillation with RVR: The patient remains tachycardic despite amiodarone drip and other rate/rhythm control methods.
7. Anemia: The patient has received multiple units of packed red blood cells and is no longer receiving blood products per family wishes.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is stable after receiving 5 units of platelets during the massive transfusion protocol.
9. Hyperglycemia: The patient is on total parenteral nutrition (TPN) with insulin and is being monitored for glucose control.
10. LFT abnormalities: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, with a cholestatic picture and transaminitis of unclear etiology.
11. Multiple myeloma: The patient is in remission after mini-allogeneic stem cell transplant, but is at risk for GVHD and is receiving immunosuppressive therapy.

The patient's current medications include:

* Ganciclovir for empiric treatment of possible CMV duodenitis
* Linezolid and gentamicin for VRE
* Cipro and levofloxacin for ESBL E. coli in urine
* Cipro and tobramycin for pseudomonas in sputum and blood
* Amiodarone for atrial fibrillation
* Insulin for hyperglycemia
* PPI for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Voriconazole for antifungal prophylaxis
* Atovaquone for antiparasitic prophylaxis

The patient's goals of care are DNR with no pressors, blood products, chest compressions, IR, or surgery. If the patient starts bleeding again, the plan is to become comfort measures only with increased pain medication as needed.

The patient's current laboratory results include:

* Hemoglobin: 11.3 g/dL
* Platelet count: 88,000/μL
* White blood cell count: 2.8 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 21 mmol/L
* Electrolytes: sodium 139 mmol/L, potassium 4.5 mmol/L, chloride 110 mmol/L
* Glucose: 178 mg/dL

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with refractory multiple myeloma who has been admitted to the ICU due to atrial fibrillation with RVR, septic shock, and hemorrhagic shock. He has undergone two IR sessions of embolization for GI bleeding and has received massive transfusion protocol with blood products.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's blood pressure is 103/57 mmHg, heart rate is 133 bpm, and oxygen saturation is 98%.
* Respiratory support: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 5 cmH2O.
* Renal function: The patient's creatinine level is 1.4 mg/dL, and he has received 7 units of packed red blood cells and 1 unit of platelets.
* Coagulation status: The patient's platelet count is 88,000/mL, and he has received 3 units of platelets.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received a total of 15,085 mL of fluid, with a balance of 6,475 mL.
* Wound care: The patient has a sacral decubitus ulcer that requires wound care.

The patient's medical complications include:

* Hemorrhagic shock: The patient has been actively bleeding, and his weight exceeds the limit of the table on the campus, making it difficult to transport him to the operating room.
* Septic shock: The patient has septic shock due to enterococcus bacteremia, which is resistant to vancomycin.
* Respiratory failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure due to his underlying medical condition and the need for mechanical ventilation.
* Acute renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure due to hypotensive episodes during hemorrhagic shock.
* Edema: The patient has developed edema due to the large amount of fluid he has received.
* Atrial fibrillation with RVR: The patient has atrial fibrillation with RVR, which is being managed with amiodarone drip and other rate/rhythm control methods.

The patient's goals of care include:

* DNR (do not resuscitate) status
* Palliative care: The patient's wife is discussing his prognosis and condition with the BMT team, our team, and surgery to decide how to proceed.
* ICU care: The patient requires continued ICU care, including mechanical ventilation, hemodynamic monitoring, and fluid management.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Further bleeding: The patient's hemorrhagic shock may continue to worsen, leading to further bleeding and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Sepsis: The patient's septic shock may progress, leading to organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure may worsen, leading to respiratory arrest and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen, leading to further renal damage and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Edema: The patient's edema may worsen, leading to respiratory compromise and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Atrial fibrillation with RVR: The patient's atrial fibrillation with RVR may worsen, leading to further cardiac complications and potentially life-threatening complications.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications, including hemorrhagic shock, septic shock, respiratory failure, acute renal failure, edema, and atrial fibrillation with RVR. The patient requires continued ICU care, including mechanical ventilation, hemodynamic monitoring, and fluid management. The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition are numerous and potentially life-threatening, and it is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his care accordingly.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* Respiratory failure, intubated, and mechanically ventilated
* Sepsis with enterococcus bacteremia resistant to vancomycin
* Massive gastrointestinal bleeding attributed to duodenal ulcer (DU)
* Anemia due to gastrointestinal blood loss
* Renal failure, at risk for acute tubular necrosis (ATN)
* Liver function test (LFT) abnormalities, likely cholestatic picture with transaminitis of unclear etiology
* Sacral decubitus ulcer
* Critically ill, with a DNR (do not resuscitate) code status

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. Respiratory failure: Prolonged mechanical ventilation, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and respiratory acidosis.
2. Sepsis: Multi-organ dysfunction, septic shock, and death.
3. Gastrointestinal bleeding: Further bleeding, hypovolemic shock, and potential for rebleeding.
4. Anemia: Further blood loss, hypovolemic shock, and potential for transfusion-related complications.
5. Renal failure: Progression to end-stage renal disease, need for dialysis, and potential for increased morbidity and mortality.
6. Liver function test abnormalities: Further liver damage, potential for liver failure, and increased risk of bleeding and coagulopathy.
7. Sacral decubitus ulcer: Worsening of the ulcer, potential for sepsis, and increased risk of mortality.
8. Nutritional support: Potential for malnutrition, impaired wound healing, and increased risk of infections.
9. Cardiovascular instability: Potential for arrhythmias, hypotension, and cardiac arrest.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and close monitoring of respiratory function.
2. Administer antibiotics to treat enterococcus bacteremia and prevent further complications.
3. Manage gastrointestinal bleeding with conservative measures and consider endoscopic intervention.
4. Monitor anemia and consider transfusions if necessary.
5. Monitor renal function and consider dialysis if necessary.
6. Manage liver function test abnormalities with supportive care and consider liver function tests every 12-24 hours.
7. Provide wound care and consider debridement for sacral decubitus ulcer.
8. Monitor nutritional status and consider enteral nutrition or parenteral nutrition if necessary.
9. Monitor cardiovascular stability and consider invasive hemodynamic monitoring if necessary.

**Plan:**

1. Continue ICU care with close monitoring of vital signs, laboratory results, and medical complications.
2. Review and update the patient's code status and advance directives as necessary.
3. Consider palliative care consultation for symptom management and end-of-life care planning.
4. Monitor the patient's condition and adjust the plan as necessary to ensure optimal care and quality of life.

Based on the patient's progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with refractory multiple myeloma, sepsis, and massive gastrointestinal bleeding. He is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure. The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.1°C (96.9°F)
* Heart rate: 125 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 133/81 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 98%
* White blood cell count: 2.8 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 11.3 g/dL
* Platelet count: 88 x 10^9/L

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: Overweight, no acute distress
* Respiratory: Endotracheal tube in place, no chest pain or wheezing
* Cardiovascular: Normal pulse and blood pressure
* Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, with bowel sounds present
* Extremities: Right and left lower extremity edema, 4+ on a scale of 4

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and creatinine, indicating possible kidney damage
* Elevated liver enzymes, suggesting liver dysfunction
* Low albumin and total protein, indicating malnutrition
* Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine, indicating possible kidney damage

The patient's medical conditions and potential complications include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated due to severe respiratory failure.
* Sepsis: The patient has bacteremia and is at risk for septic shock.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has severe gastrointestinal bleeding, which may be due to duodenal ulcer.
* Anemia: The patient has severe anemia, which is likely due to gastrointestinal blood loss.
* Renal failure: The patient is at risk for acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to sepsis and gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Liver dysfunction: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, suggesting liver dysfunction.
* Nutritional support: The patient requires total parenteral nutrition (TPN) due to malnutrition.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue mechanical ventilator support for respiratory failure
* Monitor for septic shock and treat accordingly
* Manage gastrointestinal bleeding with proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) and vasopressors
* Provide total parenteral nutrition (TPN) for malnutrition
* Monitor for renal failure and treat accordingly
* Provide wound care for sacral decubitus ulcer
* Transition to comfort care in the event of clinical decline

The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and his disposition is ICU care with no escalation of care or blood products.

 GASTROINTESTINAL BLEED, UPPER (MELENA, GI BLEED, GIB)
 BACTEREMIA
 ATRIAL FIBRILLATION (AFIB)
   61 year old gentleman with refractory multiple myeloma admitted on
   [**2165-2-25**] now with atrial fibrillation with RVR and septic shock.
   .
   # Hemorrhagic shock:  Massive GI bleed overnight [**6-29**] and through
   morning of [**6-30**] treated with massive transfusion protocol as well as
   two previous bleeds on [**6-27**] and [**6-28**] both sent to IR for embolization.
   Patient became hypotension due to upper GI bleed, not responsive to
   fluids, requiring levophed.  Received 7 units RBCs, 1 unit platelets, 5
   L IVF prior to IR embolization on [**6-27**], and 2 units PRBCs prior to
   embolization on [**6-28**].
   - continue methylprednisone at 10mg qPM in effort to decrease steroids
   to assist with ulcer healing
   - no escalation of care - no pressors, blood products, IR, surgery,
   chest compressions
   - patient is DNR/DNI
   - continue ganciclovir to empirically treat possible CMV duodenitis
   that may have caused 8 cm duodenal ulcer (bleeding source)
   .
   # Sepsis: Pt with continued enterococcus bacteremia resistant to
   vancomycin.  ID following.
   - Continue Linezolid
   - Decrease dosing of merepenem for ESBL E.coli (pt now desensitized)
   for worsening renal functions as per ID recs
   - Decrease cipro and [**Last Name (un) 614**] for pseudomonas in sputum and blood
   - HOLD gentamicin until levels <2
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Pt has been doing well on AC.
   - Continue AC vent, wean down as tolerated
   - Continue antibiotics as above
   .
   # Acute renal failure: increased to 1.6 today, likely from hypotensive
   episodes during hemorrhagic shock but also suspecting some component of
   ATN
   .
   # Anasarca: Pt received a lot of blood products and IVF for the acute
   bleeds.
   - consider diuresis
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR:  Pt remains tachycardic s/p amniodarone
   drip and many other rate/rhythm control methods.
   -Monitor HR
   .
   # Anemia: Pt s/p two IR sessions of embolization over past two days
   after massive GI bleed today with likely source being duodenal ulcer.
   Patient received 7 units pRBCs [**6-27**], 2 units [**6-28**], 19 units [**2072-6-28**].
   - trend CBC daily
   - no blood products as per family wishes
   - check and trend ionized Ca
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia
 platelets decreased to 23 today
   - no blood products
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   - on TPN with insulin
   - continue ISS
   .
   # LFT abnormalities: With e/o cholestatic picture with transaminitis of
   unclear etiology.  DDx include hemolysis, acalculous cholecystits, med
   effect, progression of GVHD to liver.
   - Trend LFTs at this time.
   .
   #. Multiple myeloma - admitted on [**2165-2-25**] now s/p mini-allogeneic SCT:
   His course has been extremely complicated and now with increasing
   immunosuppression for GVHD.  Per BMT, currently in remission.
   - appreciate BMT recs
   - cont immunosuppressants
   - cont ppx with atovaquone, ganciclovir & voriconazole
   .
   # Access
 Has R PICC, A line, R IJ
   - issue with PICC, might have been moved, needs to be reassessed today
   .
   # Sacral decubitus ulcer:
   - Wound care
   .
   # Goals of care:
    -DNR with no pressors, blood products, chest compressions, IR,
   surgery.  No escalation of care.  If/when he starts bleeding again,
   will become comfort measures only with increased pain medication as
   needed.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   TPN w/ Lipids - [**2165-7-1**] 05:41 PM 92 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:  ISS
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2165-6-26**] 02:16 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2165-6-27**] 03:18 PM
   PICC Line - [**2165-6-28**] 12:54 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: p-boots
   Stress ulcer: PPI

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications are identified:

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old gentleman with refractory multiple myeloma, atrial fibrillation, and septic shock. He has experienced massive gastrointestinal bleeding, resulting in hemorrhagic shock, and has received multiple transfusions. He has also developed enterococcus bacteremia, resistant to vancomycin, and is being treated with linezolid. The patient has respiratory failure, acute renal failure, anasarca, and thrombocytopenia. He is also experiencing hyperglycemia, liver function test abnormalities, and sacral decubitus ulcer.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hemorrhagic shock: The patient's continued bleeding may lead to further hypotension, organ dysfunction, and death.
2. Sepsis: The patient's enterococcus bacteremia may progress to septic shock, leading to multi-organ failure.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to respiratory arrest and death.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may progress to chronic renal failure, leading to end-stage renal disease.
5. Anasarca: The patient's anasarca may worsen, leading to further fluid overload and respiratory compromise.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen, leading to bleeding complications and increased risk of hemorrhage.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may worsen, leading to diabetic ketoacidosis, coma, and death.
8. Liver function test abnormalities: The patient's liver function test abnormalities may worsen, leading to liver failure and death.
9. Sacral decubitus ulcer: The patient's sacral decubitus ulcer may worsen, leading to further tissue damage, infection, and death.
10. Atrial fibrillation with RVR: The patient's atrial fibrillation with RVR may worsen, leading to cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, and death.

Based on the patient's complex medical condition and potential complications, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of his condition to prevent further deterioration and improve his outcomes.

   - continue methylprednisone at 10mg qPM in effort to decrease steroids
   to assist with ulcer healing
   - no escalation of care - no pressors, blood products, IR, surgery,
   chest compressions
   - patient is DNR
   - continue ganciclovir to empirically treat possible CMV duodenitis
   that may have caused 8 cm duodenal ulcer (bleeding source)
   .
   # Sepsis: Pt with continued enterococcus bacteremia resistant to
   vancomycin.  ID following, antibiotic regimen adjusted as per ID
   recommendations
   - Continue Linezolid
   - Decrease dosing of merepenem for ESBL E.coli and pseudomonas coverage
   to 500 mg IV q8h (day 13/14) for worsening renal functions
   - Decrease cipro for pseudomonas in sputum and blood to 400 mg IV daily
   (day [**8-29**]) for worsening renal functions
   - HOLD gentamicin until levels <2
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Pt has been doing well on AC.
   - Continue AC vent, wean down as tolerated
   - Continue antibiotics as above
   .
   # Acute renal failure: creatinine increased to 1.6 today from 1.4
   yesterday, likely from hypotensive episodes during hemorrhagic shock
   but also suspecting some component of ATN.  Gentamicin toxicity may
   also be a cause.
   - hold gentamicin until levels <2
   .
   # Anasarca: Pt received a lot of blood products and IVF for the acute
   bleeds.
   - diurese with lasix for net fluid balance of -1 L today
   - check PM electrolytes
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR:  Pt remains tachycardic s/p amniodarone
   drip and many other rate/rhythm control methods.
   -Monitor HR
   .
   # Anemia: Pt s/p two IR sessions of embolization over past two days
   after massive GI bleed today with likely source being duodenal ulcer.
   Patient received 7 units pRBCs [**6-27**], 2 units [**6-28**], 19 units [**2072-6-28**].
   - trend CBC daily
   - no blood products as per family wishes
   - check and trend ionized Ca
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia
 platelets decreased to 23 today.  Patient
s wife
   has agreed to no further blood products, but the overall impression is
   for us not to perform massive transfusion in setting of another massive
   acute bleed.  Patient is NOT comfort measures only, wife only agreed to
   no escalation of care.  By allowing platelets to continue its downward
   trend, it would precipitate the next massive bleeding episode.  For
   now, will transfuse to goal of plt >20 until further goals of care are
   discussed with family.
   - Check PM platelets
   - Transfuse platelets for goal of plt >20
   - Family meeting for goals of care
   .
   # Hyperglycemia

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with refractory multiple myeloma, atrial fibrillation with RVR, and septic shock. He has had multiple episodes of gastrointestinal bleeding, including a massive bleed overnight, which required massive transfusion protocol and embolization. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and has acute renal failure, anasarca, and thrombocytopenia. He has also developed hyperglycemia, LFT abnormalities, and a sacral decubitus ulcer.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hemorrhagic shock: The patient's history of massive GI bleeding and continued bleeding may lead to further hypovolemic shock and potential organ dysfunction.
2. Sepsis: The patient's ongoing bacteremia and septic shock may lead to further organ dysfunction and potential death.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's continued respiratory failure may lead to further lung damage and potential respiratory arrest.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient's ongoing acute renal failure may lead to further kidney damage and potential end-stage renal disease.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's continued thrombocytopenia may lead to further bleeding episodes and potential hemorrhagic shock.
6. Anasarca: The patient's ongoing anasarca may lead to further fluid overload and potential organ dysfunction.
7. Atrial fibrillation with RVR: The patient's ongoing atrial fibrillation with RVR may lead to further cardiac arrhythmias and potential cardiac arrest.
8. Hyperglycemia: The patient's ongoing hyperglycemia may lead to further metabolic complications and potential organ dysfunction.
9. LFT abnormalities: The patient's ongoing LFT abnormalities may lead to further liver damage and potential liver failure.
10. Sacral decubitus ulcer: The patient's ongoing sacral decubitus ulcer may lead to further wound complications and potential sepsis.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's current status is complex and requires close monitoring and management. The patient's DNR status and lack of escalation of care may limit the options for treatment. The patient's ongoing sepsis, respiratory failure, and acute renal failure require continued management with antibiotics, mechanical ventilation, and hemodynamic support. The patient's thrombocytopenia and anasarca require continued transfusion and diuresis, respectively. The patient's atrial fibrillation with RVR requires continued monitoring and management with rate/rhythm control medications. The patient's hyperglycemia and LFT abnormalities require continued monitoring and management with insulin and antidiabetic medications, respectively. The patient's sacral decubitus ulcer requires continued wound care and management.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with refractory multiple myeloma who was admitted on [**2165-2-25**] and developed atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and septic shock. He had a massive gastrointestinal bleed overnight and through the morning of [**6-30**], which was treated with massive transfusion protocol. The patient's condition has been complicated by numerous medical issues, including sepsis, respiratory failure, acute renal failure, anasarca, thrombocytopenia, and hyperglycemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hemorrhagic shock: The patient's recent massive gastrointestinal bleed and ongoing bleeding may lead to further hypotension and shock.
2. Sepsis: The patient's ongoing bacteremia and sepsis may lead to further organ dysfunction and mortality.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further respiratory compromise and potential need for mechanical ventilation.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient's ongoing acute renal failure may worsen, leading to further electrolyte imbalances and potential need for dialysis.
5. Anasarca: The patient's anasarca may worsen, leading to further fluid overload and potential need for diuresis.
6. Atrial fibrillation with RVR: The patient's ongoing atrial fibrillation with RVR may worsen, leading to further cardiac compromise and potential need for cardioversion.
7. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's ongoing thrombocytopenia may worsen, leading to further bleeding risk and potential need for platelet transfusions.
8. Hyperglycemia: The patient's ongoing hyperglycemia may worsen, leading to further metabolic complications and potential need for insulin adjustments.
9. LFT abnormalities: The patient's ongoing LFT abnormalities may worsen, leading to further liver dysfunction and potential need for liver support.
10. Multiple myeloma: The patient's ongoing multiple myeloma may lead to further immunosuppression and potential need for further treatment.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's goals of care are to provide comfort measures only, with no escalation of care, including no pressors, blood products, chest compressions, IR, or surgery. The patient's current plan includes:

* Continue methylprednisone to assist with ulcer healing
* Continue ganciclovir to empirically treat possible CMV duodenitis
* Continue antibiotics to treat enterococcus bacteremia
* Continue respiratory support with AC vent and wean down as tolerated
* Consider diuresis for anasarca
* Monitor HR for atrial fibrillation with RVR
* Trend CBC daily for anemia
* No blood products as per family wishes
* Check and trend ionized Ca
* Continue ISS for hyperglycemia
* Trend LFTs at this time
* Continue immunosuppressants for multiple myeloma
* Continue prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP
* Wound care for sacral decubitus ulcer

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management of multiple medical issues.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with refractory multiple myeloma, admitted on [**2165-2-25**], now with sepsis and massive GI bleeding. He remains intubated and mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure. The patient has a severe bleed attributed to a large duodenal ulcer, and no further intervention is planned. He has enterococcus bacteremia resistant to vancomycin, and antibiotics have been changed to linezolid and gentamicin. The patient has anemia attributed to GI blood loss, thrombocytopenia, and is at risk for acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to renal failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not adequately managed, leading to further complications such as pneumonia, respiratory acidosis, or cardiac arrest.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may progress to septic shock, multi-organ dysfunction, or death if not properly managed.
3. GI bleeding: The patient's severe GI bleeding may lead to hypovolemic shock, coagulopathy, or gastrointestinal perforation if not adequately managed.
4. Bacteremia: The patient's bacteremia may lead to septicemia, endocarditis, or other systemic infections if not properly managed.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not adequately managed, leading to further complications such as cardiovascular instability, respiratory failure, or increased risk of infection.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen if not adequately managed, leading to bleeding complications or increased risk of infection.
7. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure may progress to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) or acute kidney injury (AKI) if not properly managed.
8. LFT abnormalities: The patient's LFT abnormalities may worsen if not adequately managed, leading to liver failure, coagulopathy, or increased risk of bleeding.
9. Sacral decubitus ulcer: The patient's sacral decubitus ulcer may worsen if not adequately managed, leading to further complications such as sepsis, osteomyelitis, or amputation.
10. Code status: The patient's DNR (do not resuscitate) code status may lead to potential conflicts between the patient's wishes and the healthcare team's goals of care.

Recommendations:

1. Continue mechanical ventilator support to manage respiratory failure.
2. Monitor the patient's sepsis and bacteremia closely, and adjust antibiotic therapy as needed.
3. Manage the patient's GI bleeding and anemia with blood transfusions and other supportive measures.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust therapy as needed to prevent further deterioration.
5. Manage the patient's LFT abnormalities with supportive care and monitor for signs of liver failure.
6. Provide wound care for the patient's sacral decubitus ulcer to prevent further complications.
7. Respect the patient's DNR code status and prioritize comfort care and symptom management.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.4°C (97.6°F)
* Heart rate: 121 bpm (116-129 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 109/62 mmHg (77-132/93 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute (11-18 breaths per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 99%

The patient has a history of penicillin allergy, anaphylaxis, and morphine-induced nausea and vomiting. He is also receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, sedatives, and pain medications.

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: No acute distress, overweight/obese
* Eyes: PERRL (pupils equal and reactive to light), no conjunctival edema

* Neurologic: Sedated, responds to tactile stimuli, oriented to person and place

Laboratory results show:

* Platelet count: 105 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 22 mg/dL
* Glucose: 124 mg/dL
* Electrolyte imbalances: hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, and hyperphosphatemia

The patient has the following medical conditions:

* Sepsis
* Massive GI bleeding
* Respiratory failure
* Anemia
* Thrombocytopenia
* Renal failure
* LFT abnormalities
* Sacral decubitus ulcer

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue mechanical ventilator support
* Wean steroids
* Continue nutritional support with TPN
* Monitor creatinine and renal function
* Manage LFT abnormalities
* Provide wound care for sacral decubitus ulcer
* Continue current level of care, with no escalation of care or blood products, and DNR status

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Pneumonia
* Sepsis
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrest
* Renal failure
* Hepatic failure
* GI bleeding
* Anemia
* Thrombocytopenia
* Wound infection
* Sacral decubitus ulcer progression

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the plan of care accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   CMV duodenitis.

   decrease steroids to assist with ulcer healing
   - continue ganciclovir to empirically treat possible CMV duodenitis
   - no pressors, blood products, IR, surgery, chest compressions
   .

 has been adjusted for renal

has been adjusted for renal function  -d/w ID possibility of

   .
   # Respiratory failure: Most likely due to volume overload, decreased
   chest compliance given anasarca. Pt has been doing well on AC.
   - Continue AC ventilator
   .
   # Acute renal failure: creatinine stable at 1.6 today. Likely from
   hypotensive episodes during hemorrhagic shock but also suspecting some
   component of ATN.  Gentamicin toxicity may also be a cause.
   - hold gentamicin until levels <2
   .

   .

s wife has

   acute bleed.  Patient is NOT comfort measures only, wife only agreed to

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old gentleman with refractory multiple myeloma who was admitted on [**2165-2-25**] with atrial fibrillation with RVR and hemorragic shock due to a large duodenal ulcer. The patient has a complex medical history and is currently in the ICU with multiple comorbidities.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Gastrointestinal bleed: The patient has a history of GI bleeding and is currently on a lasix drip to diurese with a goal of net fluid balance of negative every hour.
* Impaired skin integrity: The patient has anasarca and is at risk for further skin breakdown.
* Shock, septic: The patient has been treated for septic shock and is currently stable.
* Respiratory failure, acute: The patient is on assisted ventilation and has a stable respiratory status.
* Anemia: The patient has a history of massive GI bleeding and is currently anemic.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a low platelet count and is at risk for further bleeding.
* Hyperglycemia: The patient is on TPN with insulin and has a history of hyperglycemia.
* LFT abnormalities: The patient has abnormal liver function tests and is at risk for further liver damage.

The patient's medical team is managing his condition with the following medications:

* Methylprednisone: 10mg qPM and 20mg qAM to decrease steroids and assist with ulcer healing.
* Ganciclovir: to empirically treat possible CMV duodenitis.
* Linezolid: to treat VRE.
* Meropenem: 500mg IV q8h to treat pseudomonas in sputum and blood.
* Cipro: 400mg IV daily to treat pseudomonas in sputum and blood.
* Lasix: to diurese with a goal of net fluid balance of negative every hour.

The patient's family has agreed to no further blood products, and the medical team is trying to manage his bleeding with medication and supportive care. The patient is not comfort measures only, and his family is willing to allow him to continue receiving treatment.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Further bleeding: The patient is at risk for further bleeding due to his low platelet count and history of GI bleeding.
* Worsening anasarca: The patient's anasarca may worsen if he continues to receive large amounts of IV fluids.
* Respiratory failure: The patient may experience further respiratory failure if his lung function worsens.
* Liver damage: The patient's liver function tests are abnormal, and he is at risk for further liver damage.
* Kidney damage: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and he is at risk for further kidney damage.
* Infection: The patient is at risk for further infection due to his immunocompromised state and history of septic shock.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

   .
   61 year old gentleman with refractory multiple myeloma admitted on
   [**2165-2-25**] with atrial fibrillation with RVR and hemorragic shock due to
   large duodenal ulcer.
   .
   # Hemorrhagic shock:  Stable. No episdoes of bleeding since [**6-30**] and
   SBP stable in 110s. Due to 8cm bleeding duodenal ulcer, possibly due to
   CMV duodenitis.
   - continue methylprednisone at 10mg qPM and 20mg qAM in effort to
   decrease steroids to assist with ulcer healing
   - continue ganciclovir to empirically treat possible CMV duodenitis
   - no pressors, blood products, IR, surgery, chest compressions
   .
   # Sepsis: Resolving. BCx [**6-26**] negative and [**Date range (1) 9544**] still pending. SBP
   stable in 100s. ID following, antibiotic regimen adjusted as per ID
   recommendations
   - Continue Linezolid for VRE as this is known source. Pt will likely
   need prolonged abx course.
   - Meropenem 500mg IV q8h (day 14/14)
 has been adjusted for renal
   function
   - Continue Cipro 400mg IV daily (day [**9-29**]) for pseudomonas in sputum
   and blood
has been adjusted for renal function  -d/w ID possibility of
   stopping this.
   - HOLD gentamicin until levels <2
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Most likely due to volume overload, decreased
   chest compliance given anasarca. Pt has been doing well on AC.
   - Continue AC ventilator
   .
   # Acute renal failure: creatinine stable at 1.6 today. Likely from
   hypotensive episodes during hemorrhagic shock but also suspecting some
   component of ATN.  Gentamicin toxicity may also be a cause.
   - hold gentamicin until levels <2
   .
   # Anasarca: Pt received a lot of blood products and IVF for the shock
   and acute bleeds. Still positive overnight despite lasix drip.
   - diurese with lasix for net fluid balance of negative every hour.
   - check PM electrolytes
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR:  Pt remains tachycardic. Not currently
   written for any rate control medications.
   -Will add beta blocker once pt is absorbing POs again.
   -Monitor HR
 may consider diltiazem IV
   .
   # Anemia: Due to massive GI bleed. Hct currently stable. No bleeds
   since [**6-30**]. Pt s/p two IR sessions of embolization after massive GI
   bleeds with likely source being duodenal ulcer.  Patient received 7
   units pRBCs [**6-27**], 2 units [**6-28**], 19 units [**2072-6-28**].
   - trend CBC daily
   - no blood products as per family wishes
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia
 platelets stable at 60 today.  Patient
s wife has
   agreed to no further blood products, but the overall impression is for
   us not to perform massive transfusion in setting of another massive
   acute bleed.  Patient is NOT comfort measures only, wife only agreed to
   no escalation of care.  By allowing platelets to continue its downward
   trend, it would precipitate the next massive bleeding episode.
   - For now, will transfuse to goal of plt >20 until further goals of
   care are discussed with family.
   - Check PM platelets
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   - on TPN with insulin
   - continue ISS
   .
   # LFT abnormalities: With e/o cholestatic picture. DDx include

   transaminitis), progression of GVHD to liver.
   - trend LFTs

   immunosuppression for GVHD.  Per BMT, currently in remission.
   - appreciate BMT recs

 have decreased steroids in effort to help

   - cont ppx with atovaquone, ganciclovir & voriconazole, although pt not

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with refractory multiple myeloma who was admitted with atrial fibrillation, hemorrhagic shock, and a large duodenal ulcer. He has undergone several interventions, including embolization and blood transfusions, and is currently receiving treatment for sepsis, respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and anasarca. His vital signs are stable, but he remains at risk for further bleeding and respiratory compromise.

Potential medical complications:

1. Continued bleeding: The patient's duodenal ulcer is a potential source of ongoing bleeding, which could lead to further hemorrhagic shock and respiratory compromise.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is fragile, and further deterioration could lead to ARDS or respiratory arrest.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine levels are stable, but he is at risk for further kidney injury due to hypotension, sepsis, and potential gentamicin toxicity.
4. Anasarca: The patient's anasarca is a significant concern, as it may be contributing to his poor wound healing and increased risk of bleeding.
5. Infection: The patient is at risk for further infection due to his immunosuppressed state and ongoing treatment with antibiotics.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is stable, but he is at risk for further bleeding due to his thrombocytopenia.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia is being managed with insulin and TPN, but he is at risk for further hyperglycemia due to his underlying condition and treatment.
8. Liver function abnormalities: The patient's liver function tests are abnormal, which may be related to his underlying condition, treatment, or other factors.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory values closely to identify any changes or trends that may indicate worsening of his condition.
2. Consider adjusting his antibiotic regimen to better target his underlying infections.
3. Continue to manage his anasarca with diuretics and monitor his fluid balance closely.
4. Consider adding a beta blocker to control his heart rate and reduce his risk of further bleeding.
5. Monitor his platelet count and transfuse as necessary to maintain a safe level.
6. Continue to manage his hyperglycemia with insulin and TPN.
7. Consider adjusting his immunosuppressive regimen to better control his underlying condition and reduce his risk of infection.
8. Monitor his liver function tests and consider adjusting his treatment regimen if necessary to address any liver function abnormalities.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with refractory multiple myeloma who was admitted on [**2165-2-25**] and has been experiencing a complex course of treatment. He is currently in the ICU with multiple comorbidities, including atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, septic shock, respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and anasarca. He has had multiple episodes of bleeding, including a massive gastrointestinal bleed, and has received blood products and IV fluids. He is currently receiving antibiotics, antivirals, and immunosuppressants, and is being treated for a possible duodenal ulcer.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate attention. The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and the differential shows a predominance of neutrophils, which may indicate an inflammatory response.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to his underlying condition and the need for mechanical ventilation. The patient's oxygen saturation is 99%, but his respiratory rate is elevated, and his PEEP is 5 cmH2O, which may indicate a need for further respiratory support.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level is 1.6 mg/dL, which is elevated, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 93 mg/dL, which is also elevated. This may indicate acute kidney injury (AKI) or chronic kidney disease (CKD).
4. Anasarca: The patient's anasarca is likely due to his underlying condition and the need for fluid resuscitation. The patient's fluid balance is positive, and his weight is increasing, which may indicate a need for further fluid removal.
5. Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response: The patient's atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate attention. The patient's heart rate is elevated, and his blood pressure is unstable, which may indicate a need for further cardiac support.
6. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate attention. The patient's bleeding has been controlled, but the source of the bleeding is still unclear, and the patient is at risk for further bleeding.
7. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is a concern, as it may increase the risk of bleeding. The patient's platelet count is 60,000/mL, which is low, and the patient's wife has agreed to no further blood products.
8. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia is a concern, as it may increase the risk of complications. The patient's blood glucose level is 83 mg/dL, which is elevated, and the patient is receiving insulin therapy.
9. Liver Function Abnormalities: The patient's liver function abnormalities are a concern, as they may indicate liver damage or disease. The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, and the patient's bilirubin level is 2.2 mg/dL, which is elevated.
10. Sacral Decubitus Ulcer: The patient's sacral decubitus ulcer is a concern, as it may increase the risk of infection and further complications. The patient's wound care is being managed, but the patient's wound is not healing, and the patient is at risk for further complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with refractory multiple myeloma, admitted on [**2165-2-25**], now with sepsis and massive gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure. His condition is complicated by bacteremia, anemia, thrombocytopenia, fluid overload, and potential renal failure. The patient has a sacral decubitus ulcer and is at risk for acute tubular necrosis (ATN). He has been desensitized to vancomycin and is being treated with linezolid and gentamicin for enterococcus bacteremia resistant to vancomycin.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to persist, and he will require continued mechanical ventilator support.
2. GI bleeding: The patient's GI bleeding is severe, and there are no plans for further intervention or escalation of care.
3. Bacteremia: The patient's bacteremia is resistant to vancomycin and requires treatment with linezolid and gentamicin.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is attributed to GI blood loss, and there are no plans for further escalation of care, including no massive transfusion with blood products.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia requires transfusion to maintain a platelet count >20.
6. Fluid overload: The patient is at risk for fluid overload due to resuscitation, and there is a desire to maintain a net negative fluid balance if tolerated.
7. Renal failure: The patient is at risk for ATN, and his creatinine levels will need to be closely monitored.
8. Sacral decubitus ulcer: The patient's sacral decubitus ulcer will require wound care.
9. LFT abnormalities: The patient's liver function test (LFT) abnormalities are likely due to a cholestatic picture with transaminitis of unclear etiology.
10. Disposition: The patient's disposition is to continue current level of care, with no escalation of care, including no blood products, and a do-not-resuscitate (DNR) status.

Based on the provided daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, a 61-year-old male with refractory multiple myeloma, has been admitted to the ICU with sepsis and massive GI bleeding. He remains intubated and mechanically ventilated due to persistent respiratory failure. The patient has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, analgesics, and sedatives.

Physically, the patient appears comfortable, with no signs of pain or distress. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.4°C (95.8°F), heart rate of 104 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 134/78 mmHg. His oxygen saturation is 100%, and he is receiving supplemental oxygen through an endotracheal tube.

The patient has been experiencing significant GI bleeding, which has been attributed to a large duodenal ulcer. He has received platelet transfusions to maintain a platelet count above 20,000/μL. His anemia is attributed to GI blood loss, and he is not receiving further transfusions.

The patient has also been experiencing thrombocytopenia, which is being managed with platelet transfusions. His fluid status is overloaded due to resuscitation, and he is receiving maximally concentrated IV medications. He is receiving TPN for nutritional support and is at risk for acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to his renal failure.

The patient has developed a sacral decubitus ulcer, which is being managed with wound care. His liver function tests (LFTs) are abnormal, with transaminitis of unclear etiology. He has a code status of DNR (do not resuscitate) and has been transitioned to comfort care in the event of clinical decline.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for further sepsis due to his ongoing bacteremia and GI bleeding.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, requiring further escalation of ventilator support.
3. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure may progress to ATN, requiring further management.
4. Liver failure: The patient's LFT abnormalities may indicate liver failure, requiring further evaluation and management.
5. Wound infection: The patient's sacral decubitus ulcer is at risk for infection, requiring close monitoring and wound care.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen, requiring further platelet transfusions.
7. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid overload may worsen, requiring further management and monitoring.

Based on the patient's current condition, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of his various medical conditions to prevent further complications and ensure his comfort and well-being.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with refractory multiple myeloma, atrial fibrillation with RVR, and hemorragic shock due to a large duodenal ulcer. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. His current vital signs include a temperature of 35.4°C, heart rate of 104 bpm, and blood pressure of 126/77 mmHg. His respiratory support includes an endotracheal tube, ventilator mode, and oxygen delivery device.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Hemorrhagic shock: The patient has had several episodes of bleeding, including a large duodenal ulcer, and is currently receiving supportive care.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a known source of infection and is receiving antibiotic therapy.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient has acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and is receiving mechanical ventilation.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient has a creatinine level of 1.6 mg/dL and is receiving dialysis.
5. Anasarca: The patient has edema and is receiving diuretic therapy.
6. Atrial fibrillation with RVR: The patient has atrial fibrillation and is receiving rate control medication.
7. Anemia: The patient has a hemoglobin level of 10.2 g/dL and is receiving blood transfusions.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a platelet count of 60,000/μL and is receiving platelet transfusions.
9. Hyperglycemia: The patient has a blood glucose level of 108 mg/dL and is receiving insulin therapy.
10. LFT abnormalities: The patient has elevated liver enzymes and is receiving antiviral therapy.

The patient's goals of care are:

1. DNR (do not resuscitate) with no pressors, blood products, chest compressions, IR, or surgery.
2. No escalation of care. If the patient starts bleeding again, he will become comfort measures only with increased pain medication as needed.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Further bleeding: The patient is at risk of further bleeding due to his ongoing medical conditions and the need for continued invasive procedures.
2. Sepsis: The patient is at risk of developing sepsis due to his known source of infection and the need for continued antibiotic therapy.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk of developing further respiratory failure due to his ongoing medical conditions and the need for continued mechanical ventilation.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient is at risk of developing further acute renal failure due to his ongoing medical conditions and the need for continued dialysis.
5. Anasarca: The patient is at risk of developing further anasarca due to his ongoing medical conditions and the need for continued diuretic therapy.
6. Atrial fibrillation with RVR: The patient is at risk of developing further atrial fibrillation and RVR due to his ongoing medical conditions and the need for continued rate control medication.
7. Anemia: The patient is at risk of developing further anemia due to his ongoing medical conditions and the need for continued blood transfusions.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient is at risk of developing further thrombocytopenia due to his ongoing medical conditions and the need for continued platelet transfusions.
9. Hyperglycemia: The patient is at risk of developing further hyperglycemia due to his ongoing medical conditions and the need for continued insulin therapy.
10. LFT abnormalities: The patient is at risk of developing further LFT abnormalities due to his ongoing medical conditions and the need for continued antiviral therapy.

   SBP stable in 110s. Due to 8cm bleeding duodenal ulcer, possibly due to
   CMV duodenitis.
   - continue methylprednisone at 10mg qPM and 20mg qAM in effort to
   decrease steroids to assist with ulcer healing
   - continue ganciclovir to empirically treat possible CMV duodenitis
   - no pressors, blood products, IR, surgery, chest compressions
   .
   # Sepsis: Resolving. BCx [**6-26**], [**6-27**], [**6-28**] all negative. SBP stable. ID

   and blood
has been adjusted for renal function  -d/w ID possibility of

   .

   chest compliance given anasarca. Pt has been doing well on AC.
   - Continue AC ventilator
   .

   hypotensive episodes during hemorrhagic shock but also suspecting some
   component of ATN.  Gentamicin toxicity may also be a cause.
   - hold gentamicin until levels <2
   .

   and acute bleeds. Still positive overnight despite lasix drip.
   - diurese with lasix for net fluid balance of negative every hour.
   - check PM electrolytes
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR:  Pt remains tachycardic. Not currently
   written for any rate control medications.
   -Will add beta blocker once pt is absorbing POs again.
   -Monitor HR
 may consider diltiazem IV
   .

   .

   us not to perform massive transfusion in setting of another massive
   acute bleed.  Patient is NOT comfort measures only, wife only agreed to

   trend, it would precipitate the next massive bleeding episode.
   - For now, will transfuse to goal of plt >20 until further goals of

   - Check PM platelets

   - continue ISS

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old gentleman with refractory multiple myeloma, atrial fibrillation with RVR, and hemorragic shock due to a large duodenal ulcer. The patient has undergone multiple interventions, including embolization, and has received various medications, including antibiotics, antivirals, and immunosuppressants.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is intubated and on assisted ventilation (AC) due to respiratory failure, likely caused by volume overload and decreased chest compliance.
* Hemodynamic status: The patient's blood pressure is stable, and he has not experienced any episodes of bleeding since June 30th.
* Renal status: The patient has acute renal failure, with a creatinine level of 1.7 mg/dL, and is at risk for gentamicin toxicity.
* Coagulation status: The patient has thrombocytopenia, with a platelet count of 26, and is at risk for bleeding.
* Fluid status: The patient has anasarca, with a net fluid balance of positive overnight, despite receiving lasix drips.
* Gastrointestinal status: The patient has a duodenal ulcer, which is likely due to CMV duodenitis, and has undergone embolization.
* Infectious status: The patient has negative blood cultures and is being treated empirically for possible CMV duodenitis.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for developing sepsis due to his immunocompromised state and the presence of a duodenal ulcer.
2. Bleeding: The patient is at risk for bleeding due to his thrombocytopenia and the presence of a duodenal ulcer.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require further interventions to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's renal function is compromised, and he may be at risk for further kidney damage.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient is at risk for further gastrointestinal bleeding due to the presence of a duodenal ulcer and his immunocompromised state.
6. Infection: The patient is at risk for developing infections due to his immunocompromised state and the presence of a duodenal ulcer.

The patient's goals of care are to remain in comfort measures only, with no escalation of care, and to receive pain management as needed. The patient's wife has agreed to this plan, and the patient's care will be focused on maintaining his comfort and preventing further complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with refractory multiple myeloma, admitted with atrial fibrillation with RVR and hemorrhagic shock due to a large duodenal ulcer. He has undergone multiple interventions, including embolization and transfusions. Currently, he is intubated and on mechanical ventilation, with a goal of weaning him off the ventilator. His condition is complicated by anasarca, acute renal failure, and thrombocytopenia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Bleeding: Given the patient's history of massive GI bleed and ongoing bleeding duodenal ulcer, there is a high risk of further bleeding episodes.
2. Sepsis: The patient has had multiple episodes of sepsis, and there is a risk of further infections, particularly with the presence of a central line and urinary catheter.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is precarious, and there is a risk of further deterioration, particularly with the presence of anasarca and decreased chest compliance.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine levels are stable, but there is a risk of further kidney injury due to hypotensive episodes and potential gentamicin toxicity.
5. Anasarca: The patient's fluid balance is not optimal, and there is a risk of further fluid accumulation, particularly with the presence of a positive fluid balance.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, and there is a risk of further bleeding episodes.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient has hyperglycemia, and there is a risk of further glucose fluctuations with the use of insulin and TPN.
8. LFT abnormalities: The patient has abnormal LFTs, and there is a risk of further liver damage, particularly with the presence of cholestatic features.
9. Sacral decubitus ulcer: The patient has a sacral decubitus ulcer, and there is a risk of further wound complications.
10. Goals of care: The patient's goals of care are DNR with no escalation of care, which may lead to a lack of aggressive management of potential complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's bleeding status and adjust management accordingly.
2. Continue to optimize his fluid balance and electrolyte levels.
3. Monitor his platelet count and transfuse as necessary.
4. Continue to manage his hyperglycemia and LFT abnormalities.
5. Continue to provide wound care for his sacral decubitus ulcer.
6. Discuss the patient's goals of care with his family and ensure that they are aware of the potential complications and risks involved.
7. Consider adding beta blockers to control his tachycardia.
8. Consider adjusting his antibiotic regimen to address potential infections.
9. Monitor his respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as necessary.
10. Continue to provide palliative care to ensure the patient's comfort and dignity.

   61yom refractory multiple myeloma, admitted on [**2165-2-25**], and now with
   sepsis and massive GI bleeding.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE -- persistent.  Multifactorial.  Continue
   mechanical ventilator support.  Hope to work towards SBT and extubation
   trial -- main obstacles to extubation include volume overload,
   sedation.
   GI BLEED -- severe bleed, attributed to large DU.  No further
   intervention.  No plans for escalation of care, including no massive
   blood products. Plan to wean steroids, continue nutritional support.
   No plans for surgery.  Continue gancyclovir for possible CMV
   duodenitis.

   --> Linezolid and gent for VRE, continue [**Name (NI) 9261**] (pt now
   desensitized), Cipro
   ANEMIA -- attributed predominately to GI blood loss.  No further
   escalation of care, including no massive transfusion with blood
   products.
   THROMBOCYTOPENIA -- transfuse to maintain plts >20
   FLUIDS -- total body overloaded due to ressusitation .  Desire net
   negative if tolerates.  Maximally concentrate all iv meds.
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT -- TPN.
   GVHD -- continue usual meds.  Now on lower dose steroids.
   RASH -- on hands --> ?sloughing of skin vs active GVHD
   RENAL FAILURE -- monitor creatinine.  At risk for ATN.
   LFT abnormalities -- likely cholestatic picture with transaminitis of
   unclear etiology.
   SACRAL DECUBITUS ULCER -- Wound care.
   DISPOSITION -- Per discussion with wife, no escalation of care
   (incuding no blood products) and DNR (no CPR).  In the event of
   clinical decline, transition to comfort care.  Continue current level
   of care.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress as follows:

The patient, a 61-year-old male with refractory multiple myeloma, is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure. He has a history of sepsis and massive gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding, which is attributed to a large duodenal ulcer. The patient has a complex medical condition, with multiple comorbidities, including bacteremia, anemia, thrombocytopenia, fluid overload, and renal failure.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.5°C (95.9°F), heart rate of 119 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 147/88 mmHg. He has a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 97%. His physical examination reveals signs of fluid overload, with bilateral lower extremity edema, and a rash on his hands.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 2.3, hemoglobin of 10.2 g/dL, and platelet count of 81. His creatinine level is 1.4 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 26 mg/dL. His liver function tests (LFTs) show elevated levels of alkaline phosphatase, alanine aminotransferase (ALT), and aspartate aminotransferase (AST).

The patient's plan of care includes continued mechanical ventilator support, with a goal of weaning him off the ventilator and eventually extubating him. He will also continue to receive nutritional support through total parenteral nutrition (TPN). His medications will be adjusted as needed to manage his symptoms and comorbidities.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if he is not weaned off the ventilator and eventually extubated.
2. GI bleeding: The patient's GI bleeding may continue or worsen, leading to further blood loss and potential complications.
3. Bacteremia: The patient's bacteremia may lead to septicemia and potential organ failure if not adequately treated.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if he continues to lose blood, leading to potential complications such as cardiac arrest.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen if he continues to receive blood products or if his platelet count does not improve.
6. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid overload may worsen if he continues to receive IV fluids or if his kidneys are unable to effectively remove excess fluid.
7. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure may worsen if he continues to experience fluid overload or if his kidneys are unable to effectively remove waste products.
8. LFT abnormalities: The patient's LFT abnormalities may worsen if he continues to experience liver dysfunction or if his liver function does not improve.

Overall, the patient's complex medical condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and improve his outcome.

   blood products. Plan to wean steroids, continue nutritional support.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with refractory multiple myeloma who is currently admitted to the ICU with sepsis and massive gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient's condition is complex and multifactorial, with multiple potential complications.

The patient's respiratory status is critical, with persistent respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilator support. The main obstacles to extubation are volume overload and sedation.

The patient has severe gastrointestinal bleeding attributed to a large duodenal ulcer, with no further intervention planned. The patient is also experiencing bacteremia, likely due to enterococcus, which is resistant to vancomycin. The patient is being treated with linezolid and gentamicin, and ciprofloxacin.

The patient has anemia, primarily due to gastrointestinal blood loss, and thrombocytopenia, which is being managed with platelet transfusions. The patient has fluid overload, which is being managed with diuretics and fluid restriction. The patient is also experiencing nutritional deficiencies, which are being managed with total parenteral nutrition (TPN).

The patient has a history of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD), which is being managed with standard medications. The patient is also experiencing a rash on his hands, which may be due to sloughing of skin or active GVHD.

The patient has renal failure, which is being monitored, and is at risk for acute tubular necrosis (ATN). The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are abnormal, with a cholestatic picture and transaminitis of unclear etiology.

The patient has a sacral decubitus ulcer, which is being managed with wound care. The patient's disposition is DNR (do not resuscitate), and in the event of clinical decline, the patient will be transitioned to comfort care.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration, which could lead to respiratory arrest or failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient has bacteremia, which can lead to sepsis, organ dysfunction, and death.
3. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has severe gastrointestinal bleeding, which can lead to hypovolemic shock, organ failure, and death.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has thrombocytopenia, which can lead to bleeding complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. Fluid overload: The patient has fluid overload, which can lead to congestive heart failure, pulmonary edema, and death.
6. Renal failure: The patient has renal failure, which can lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and death.
7. Liver failure: The patient's LFTs are abnormal, which can lead to liver failure, encephalopathy, and death.
8. Graft-versus-host disease: The patient has a history of GVHD, which can lead to organ failure, including liver and gut failure.
9. Sacral decubitus ulcer: The patient has a sacral decubitus ulcer, which can lead to sepsis, organ failure, and death.

In summary, the patient is a complex case with multiple potential complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further deterioration and improve outcomes.

   [**2165-2-25**] with atrial fibrillation with RVR and hemorragic shock due to

   CMV duodenitis.

   to assist with ulcer healing
   - s/p ganciclovir to empirically treat possible CMV duodenitis (stopped
   [**12-17**] lowering WBC count)
   - no pressors, blood products, IR, surgery, chest compressions
   .
   # Sepsis: Resolving. BCx [**6-26**], [**6-27**], [**6-28**] all negative. SBP stable. ID
   following, antibiotic regimen adjusted as per ID recommendations
   - Continue Linezolid for VRE as this is known source. Pt will likely
   need prolonged abx course.
   - Continue Cipro 400mg IV daily (day [**10-29**]) for pseudomonas in sputum
   and blood
   - HOLD gentamicin until levels <2
   - completed 14 day course of Meropenem for ESBL E. coli in his urine
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Most likely due to volume overload, decreased
   chest compliance given anasarca. Pt has been doing well on AC.
   - Continue AC ventilator
   .
   # Acute renal failure: creatinine stable at 1.7 today. Likely from
   hypotensive episodes during hemorrhagic shock but also suspecting some
   component of ATN.  Gentamicin toxicity may also be a cause.
   - hold gentamicin until levels <2
   .
   # Anasarca: Pt received a lot of blood products and IVF for the shock
   and acute bleeds. Still positive overnight despite lasix drip.
   - diurese with lasix for net fluid balance of negative every hour.
   - check PM electrolytes
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR:  Pt remains tachycardic. Not currently
   written for any rate control medications.
   -Will add beta blocker once pt is absorbing POs again.
   -Monitor HR
 may consider diltiazem IV
   .

   bleeds with likely source being duodenal ulcer.  Patient received 7
   units pRBCs [**6-27**], 2 units [**6-28**], 19 units [**2072-6-28**].
   - trend CBC daily
   - no blood products as per family wishes
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia
 platelets down to 18 this AM.  Patient
s wife has

   us not to perform massive transfusion in setting of another massive
   acute bleed.  Patient is NOT comfort measures only, wife only agreed to
   no escalation of care.  By allowing platelets to continue its downward
   trend, it would precipitate the next massive bleeding episode.
   - For now, will transfuse to goal of plt >20 until further goals of
   care are discussed with family.
   - Check PM platelets
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   - on TPN with insulin
   - continue ISS
   .
   # LFT abnormalities: With e/o cholestatic picture. DDx include
   hemolysis, acalculous cholecystits, med effect (gancyclovir gives
   transaminitis), progression of GVHD to liver.
   - trend LFTs
   .
   #. Multiple myeloma - admitted on [**2165-2-25**] now s/p mini-allogeneic SCT:
   His course has been extremely complicated and now with increasing
   immunosuppression for GVHD.  Per BMT, currently in remission.

 have decreased steroids in effort to help

   - cont ppx with atovaquone, ganciclovir & voriconazole, although pt not

   .

   - Wound care
   .
